thread.title: Brandis takes aim at Wong after Question Time attack on One Nation
thread.title_full: Brandis takes aim at Wong after Question Time attack on One Nation

author: Henry Belot
title: Brandis takes aim at Wong after Question Time attack on One Nation
text:
Map: WA 
Attorney-General George Brandis has accused Labor Senator Penny Wong of having an "unhealthy obsession" with Pauline Hanson after she launched a fiery attack on One Nation. 
The West Australian Liberals have decided to preference One Nation above the Nationals in the Upper House in regional areas , with One Nation preferencing the Liberals in all Lower House seats in return. 
Senior Liberal figures have dismissed the deal as a matter for WA Liberal Party officials, but it dominated debate during a testy Question Time on Monday. 
Senator Wong took issue with Industry Minister Arthur Sinodinos's comments describing One Nation as "sophisticated" compared to when Senator Hanson first entered Parliament. 
"They're more sophisticated because in this chamber, since they've been here, they've supported important pieces of Government legislation, they've been prepared to work with us," Senator Sinodinos said. Video: Arthur Sinodinos says Pauline Hanson's party is a "different beast" to 20 years ago. (ABC News) 
Senator Wong said it was not One Nation that have changed since the late 1990s, but the Liberal Party. 
"Is it Senator Hanson's plan to scrap the GST and replace it with a 2 per cent tax on everything including pensioners and the poor; or One Nation's plan to force everyone to sign a prenuptial agreement; or her plans to fingerprint everyone in the nation and then force them to provide their fingerprint before they can access Medicare?," she asked. 
Former prime minister John Howard decided in 2000 that One Nation should be placed last on all Liberal Party how-to-vote cards, claiming Ms Hanson was fanning "racist sentiment". 
Senator Wong said Mr Howard had more conviction and principles than the current Liberal leadership. 
"This is a government that is prepared to sell out on its principles and to do what John Howard was not prepared to do; to trade with One Nation and Senator Hanson," Senator Wong said. 
"They are desperate to govern with them and they now believe they will not be elected without their support." 'You have what is bordering upon an unhealthy obsession' 
Senator Brandis defended the One Nation leader and told Senator Wong to "get used" to her influence in the Upper House. The success of the Liberal Party's preference deal with One Nation in WA could hang on how many support staff are available on election day, a political analyst says. 
"I know you have a sensitivity about One Nation. I know that you have what is bordering upon an unhealthy obsession with Senator Hanson, but Senator Wong, get used to it," he said. 
"There any many issues — I dare say most issues — in which I profoundly disagree with Senator Hanson but nevertheless, unlike Senator Wong, I do find it perfectly easy to treat her with professional courtesy." 
Opposition Leader Bill Shorten accused the Prime Minister of "cuddling up" to One Nation earlier on Monday. 
The Liberals and Nationals in Western Australia have a more antagonistic relationship in WA than they do in the eastern states. 
The two parties are in power together, but they do not govern in a formal coalition. 
The deal has angered Nationals heavyweights in Canberra, who are increasingly concerned about the electoral challenge that a resurgent One Nation poses in regional areas. 'Get out your tissues', Hanson tells Labor 
Senator Hanson said Labor's attack on the preference deal was "pathetic" and said her policies would be judged by the Australian electorate. 
"Here you are in this chamber talking about One Nation and the preference deal, that is a state issue and has nothing to do with federal [politics]. I think it's a pathetic, I really do," she said. 
"You should be absolutely ashamed of yourself. 
"The fact is you should get out your tissues, tears running down your cheeks, because you haven't been able to preference deals with us," she said. 
Senator Hanson said she had been validly elected to the Senate and the people of Australia would judge her policies accordingly. 
"If I say anything extreme they will judge me, but you actually judge me because you are afraid you may lose your seat to One Nation." 
The One Nation leader said the preference deal was not an attempt to "prop-up" the Colin Barnett Government, and said how-to-vote cards were only suggestions to voters. 
"The fact is I will not apologise for being a patriotic Australian and standing up for Australian values and the Australian people," she said.
